questions.text: Which psychosexual stage is associated with the development of gender identity and the formation of the superego?
questions.solution:
The phallic stage, which occurs between ages 3 to 5, is crucial for the development of gender identity as children experience unconscious fantasies about the opposite-sex parent. It also plays a significant role in the formation of the superego, which helps in internalizing parental influences and social rules. The genital stage focuses more on sexual identity and relationships, while the oral and latency stages focus on different developmental aspects.

Freud's Psychosexual Stages:

  1. Oral Stage (0-18 months):
    • Focus on mouth and sucking reflex.
    • Involves libidinal and aggressive drives.
    • Successful resolution leads to trust and self-reliance.
    • Maladaptive outcomes: optimism, narcissism, or dependency.
  2. Anal Stage (1-3 years):
    • Focus on control over sphincters, especially during toilet training.
    • Conflicts with parents over control.
    • Successful resolution fosters autonomy and independence.
    • Maladaptive outcomes: orderliness, obstinacy, and defiance.
  3. Urethral Stage (Transitional stage between anal and phallic stages):
    • Pleasure from urination and issues of control.
    • Develops traits like competitiveness and ambition.
    • Plays a role in gender identity and self-competence.
  4. Phallic Stage (3-5 years):
    • Focus on genital area and sexual interest.
    • Children develop unconscious fantasies about the opposite-sex parent.
    • Leads to the development of gender identity and the superego.
    • Pathological traits related to Oedipal conflicts and parental influences.
  5. Latency Stage (5-6 to 11-13 years):
    • Period of sexual drive quiescence.
    • Focus on skill development, peer relationships, and mastery.
    • Superego development aids impulse control.
    • Important for social skills and gender identity formation.
  6. Genital Stage (11-13 years to adulthood):
    • Onset of puberty and intensified libidinal drives.
    • Focus on establishing mature sexual relationships and adult roles.
    • Resolution of previous conflicts leads to a cohesive identity.
    • Successful resolution leads to the ability to engage in meaningful work and relationships.

Tags :

  • Topic : Sigmund Freud, Psychosexual development
  • Difficulty Level: Good to know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 34, Page Number: 3332

questions.text: Which cognitive developmental stage is seen in a normal child of age 10 months?
questions.solution:
• Jean Piaget (1896-1980) is a key figure in 20th-century known for his groundbreaking contributions to cognitive development.
  • Piaget is recognized primarily as a genetic epistemologist, focusing on how children develop abstract thought based on biological and innate factors. His aim was to explain the progressive development of human knowledge.
  • Piaget identified four major stages of cognitive development. Each stage builds on the previous one, with individual progression influenced by innate abilities and environmental factors.

Tags :

  • Topic : Jean Piaget, Cognitive development
  • Difficulty Level: Must know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 34, Page Number:3163

questions.text: 'I know that there is someone behind me on the right all the time; he moves when I move'.Identify the type of hallucination.
questions.solution:
Option A: Visual hallucination

  • Visual hallucinations involve perceiving images or scenes that aren't present in reality. These can range from simple shapes or colors to complex, life like figures.
  • Individuals may see things like distorted objects, people, or flashes of light.
  • Often associated with conditions such as schizophrenia, delirium, or neurological disorders, they can evoke strong emotional responses, leading to distress or confusion.

Option B: Reflex hallucination

  • Reflex hallucinations involve a sensory stimulus triggering a perception in another modality, akin to synaesthesia. For instance, a patient felt writing in her abdomen while a doctor documented notes.
  • Similarly, another woman experienced pain linked to specific words. While not diagnostically significant, recognizing these phenomena aids in identifying more critical symptoms.

Option C: Functional hallucination

  • Functional hallucinations occur when external stimuli, like running water or electronic devices, trigger simultaneous auditory hallucinations.
  • Patients can distinguish these hallucinations from reality, yet they experience significant distress, often leading to fear or violent reactions to the perceived threats.

Option D: Extracampine hallucination

  • It occurs when individuals perceive stimuli outside their immediate sensory range.
  • This includes sensations of unseen presences nearby and distant sounds, like conversations about their condition, creating a disconnection from reality and challenging the boundaries of perception and awareness.

Tags :

  • Topic : Hallucination
  • Difficulty Level: Good to know

Reference: SIMS Psychopathology, 7th Edition, Chapter 7, Page Number:105

choices.text: Sensory experiences that are perceived outside the body and are uncontrollable
Sensory experiences that occur within the subjective space of the individual and can be controlled
Sensory experiences that are recognized as not real by the individual experiencing them
Sensory experiences that are perceived as real and uncontrollable but are not recognized as false

questions.text: Which of the following best describes pseudohallucinations?
questions.solution:
Pseudohallucinations are experiences that occur within the subjective space of the individual, meaning they are perceived internally rather than externally. These experiences are also controllable by the individual, unlike true hallucinations, which are uncontrollable and perceived as real. Option A refers more to true hallucinations, while options C and D describe aspects of true hallucinations or confound the nature of pseudohallucinations.


Phantom Limb:

  • Definition: A condition where individuals feel sensations (including pain or discomfort) in a limb that has been amputated or is missing.
  • Cause: Occurs due to changes in the brain and nervous system following the loss of the limb.

Autoscopy:

  • Definition: The experience of seeing an image of oneself in external space, often referred to as the "phantom mirror image".
  • Types of Autoscopy:
    • Autoscopic hallucinations
    • Heautoscopy
    • Feelings of presence
    • Out-of-body experiences
    • Negative autoscopy
  • Characteristics: These experiences often involve visual perception anomalies and feelings of detachment.

Illusions:

  • Definition: A perceptual experience where the individual perceives something that differs from reality.
  • Types: Can involve visual, auditory, or sensory distortions, leading to misinterpretations of stimuli.
  • Cause: Illusions reveal how the brain organizes and interprets sensory information, often influenced by context and expectations.

Tags :

  • Topic : Pseudohallucination
  • Difficulty Level: Must know

Reference: SIMS Psychopathology, 7th Edition, Chapter 7, Page Number:104

questions.text: Which is not a symptom of serotonin syndrome?
questions.solution:
Serotonin Syndrome:

  • Serotonin syndrome results from toxic levels of serotonin due to the concurrent use of SSRIs, MAOIs, L-tryptophan, or lithium. It presents a serious risk of overstimulation of serotonin receptors.
  • Symptoms Progression

The symptoms of serotonin syndrome worsen progressively:

  1. Diarrhea
  2. Restlessness
  3. Extreme agitation, hyperreflexia, and autonomic instability
  4. Myoclonus, seizures, hyperthermia, and rigidity
  5. Delirium, coma, cardiovascular collapse, and potentially death
  • Treatment Approaches
    • Management involves removing the offending agents and providing comprehensive supportive care, which may include medications like cyproheptadine, nitroglycerine, and benzodiazepines, along with cooling measures and mechanical ventilation.
  • Importance of Prompt Recognition
    • Early recognition and treatment are crucial in preventing severe complications or fatalities associated with serotonin syndrome. Immediate medical intervention can significantly improve outcomes.

SSRI Withdrawal:

  • Abrupt discontinuation of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), especially those with shorter half-lives like paroxetine and fluvoxamine, can lead to withdrawal symptoms.
  • Symptoms
    • Withdrawal symptoms may include dizziness, weakness, nausea, rebound depression, anxiety, insomnia, poor concentration, and migraine-like effects.
  • Duration and Recovery
    • Symptoms typically emerge after six weeks of treatment and usually resolve spontaneously within three weeks. Fluoxetine is least likely to cause withdrawal due to its long half-life and is sometimes used to mitigate discontinuation symptoms from other SSRIs.

Tags :

  • Topic : SSRI, Serotonin syndrome
  • Difficulty Level: Must know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 21, Page Number:1990

choices.text: To diagnose mental health disorders like depression
To assess cognitive function and track changes over time
To evaluate emotional and psychological health
To test for neurological diseases like multiple sclerosis

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)?
questions.solution:
The MMSE is primarily used to assess cognitive function, identify cognitive impairment, and monitor changes over time. It is commonly used in diagnosing dementia, Alzheimer's disease, and other cognitive disorders.

Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE):

Introduction

  • The MMSE is a brief, structured tool used to assess cognitive function.
  • It helps in the screening, diagnosis, and monitoring of cognitive impairment, particularly in conditions like dementia.
  • Developed by Marshal F. Folstein and colleagues in 1975.

Purpose

  • Used primarily to assess cognitive impairment and track changes over time.
  • Helps in diagnosing conditions like Alzheimer’s disease, dementia, and other cognitive disorders.
  • Can be used to differentiate between types of cognitive disorders and assess severity.

Structure of MMSE

  • The MMSE consists of 11 questions that assess different cognitive domains, including orientation, registration, attention, recall, language, and visuospatial abilities.
  • It is scored out of 30 points, with each section contributing a different number of points.

Components and Scoring

  • Orientation (10 points): Assesses orientation to time and place.
    • Year, season, date, day of the week (5 points).
    • Current location (city, state, building, floor) (5 points).
  • Registration (3 points): Assesses short-term memory.
    • The examiner names 3 objects (e.g., "apple," "table," "penny"), and the patient must repeat them.
    • Scoring: 1 point for each correctly repeated object (maximum 3 points).
  • Attention and Calculation (5 points): Assesses concentration and attention.
    • Subtest 1: The patient is asked to subtract 7 from 100 repeatedly (e.g., 100, 93, 86, etc.).
    • Subtest 2: Alternatively, the patient can spell “WORLD” backward.
    • The correct response for subtraction or backward spelling yields points (maximum 5 points).
  • Recall (3 points): Assesses short-term memory.
    • The patient is asked to recall the 3 objects named earlier in the registration phase.
    • One point is given for each correct answer (maximum 3 points).
  • Language (8 points): Assesses language abilities, including naming, repetition, comprehension, reading, and writing.
    • Naming (2 points): The patient is asked to name two objects (e.g., a pen and a watch).
    • Repetition (1 point): The patient is asked to repeat a sentence, such as "No ifs, ands, or buts".
    • Comprehension (1 point): The patient follows a two-step command (e.g., "Take this paper in your right hand, fold it in half").
    • Reading (1 point): The patient reads and follows a written instruction (e.g., "Close your eyes").
    • Writing (1 point): The patient is asked to write a sentence spontaneously.
    • Drawing (1 point): The patient is asked to draw a clock showing 10:10 (assesses visuospatial and executive function).

Scoring and Interpretation

  • Total Score: The MMSE is scored out of a total of 30 points.
  • Interpretation:
    • 25–30 points: No cognitive impairment.
    • 21–24 points: Mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
    • 10–20 points: Moderate cognitive impairment.
    • 0–9 points: Severe cognitive impairment.
  • Cutoff Scores: Cutoff scores may vary by education level and cultural factors. Generally, a score of <24 suggests cognitive impairment.

Strengths of the MMSE

  • Quick and easy to administer: Takes about 5–10 minutes to complete.
  • Widely used: Standardized and widely accepted in clinical settings.
  • Good for tracking changes over time: Useful in monitoring the progression of cognitive impairment or the effects of treatment.

Limitations of the MMSE

  • Cultural and educational biases: Performance can be affected by the patient's level of education, language, and cultural background.
  • Does not assess all cognitive domains: The MMSE primarily focuses on basic cognitive functions and may miss subtle deficits in executive function or other higher-order cognitive abilities.
  • Sensitivity and specificity issues: The MMSE may not be sensitive enough to detect early-stage dementia or mild cognitive impairment, particularly in well-educated individuals.

Clinical Use

  • Screening: MMSE is frequently used for initial cognitive screening in patients with suspected dementia or cognitive decline.
  • Diagnosis: Used to help support the diagnosis of conditions like Alzheimer's disease, vascular dementia, or delirium.
  • Monitoring: MMSE is used over time to monitor the progression of cognitive decline or to assess response to treatment.

Advantages and Disadvantages

  • Advantages:
    • Quick and easy to use.
    • Can be done in any healthcare setting (e.g., hospitals, clinics, nursing homes).
    • Helps assess baseline cognitive status and track changes over time.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Limited scope for evaluating the full range of cognitive functions.
    • May be influenced by factors like education, mood, or hearing and vision impairments.

Tags :

  • Topic : MMSE
  • Difficulty Level: Good to know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 1, Page Number:145

questions.text: CAGE questionnaire is used in which Psychiatry disorder?
questions.solution:
CAGE Questionnaire

  1. Cut down: Have you ever tried to cut down on your drinking?
  2. Annoyed: Have people annoyed you by criticizing your drinking?
  3. Guilty: Have you ever felt bad or guilty about your drinking?
  4. Eye-opener: Have you ever had a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or to get rid of a hangover?

Option A: Depression

Scales used:

  1. Hamilton depression scale (Ham-d)
  2. Beck depression inventory (BDI)
  3. Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9)

Option B: Schizophrenia

  1. Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS)
  2. Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS)

Option C: OCD

  1. Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (Y-BOCS)
  2. Obsessive-Compulsive Inventory-Revised (OCI-R)

Option D: Alcohol use disorder

  1. Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT)
  2. CAGE Questionnaire
  3. Clinical Institute Withdrawal Assessment for Alcohol (CIWA-Ar)

Tags :

  • Topic : MSE, Alcohol use disorder
  • Difficulty Level: Must know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 1, Page Number:43

questions.text: What is an absolute contraindication of ECT: Electroconvulsive therapy?
questions.solution:
Contraindications of ECT:

  • No Absolute Contraindications: ECT has no absolute contraindications, only situations with increased risk that require close monitoring.
  • Pregnancy: Pregnancy is not a contraindication for ECT; fetal monitoring is typically unnecessary unless the pregnancy is high risk or complicated.
  • CNS Lesions: Patients with space-occupying central nervous system lesions are at increased risk for edema and brain herniation. Dexamethasone pretreatment and hypertension control can mitigate these risks.
  • Intracerebral Pressure: Those with increased intracranial pressure or risks of cerebral bleeding (e.g., cerebrovascular diseases) face risks due to elevated cerebral blood flow during seizures. Blood pressure control is essential.
  • Recent Myocardial Infarctions: Patients with recent heart attacks are at higher risk, but this risk significantly decreases two weeks post-infarction and is further reduced three months later.
  • Hypertension Management: Patients with hypertension should be stabilized on antihypertensive medications before ECT. Propranolol and sublingual nitroglycerin can provide additional protection during treatment.

Tags :

  • Topic: ECT, Contraindications
  • Difficulty Level: Must know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 22, Page Number:2312

questions.text: Which of the following treatments is specifically used to prevent chronic migraines?
questions.solution:
CGRP inhibitors, like Erenumab, are a newer class of drugs used for migraine prevention, especially in chronic migraine cases. NSAIDs and ergotamines are typically used for acute treatment, while acupuncture is a non-pharmacological option that may help reduce migraine frequency.

MIGRAINE:

Etiology

  • Genetic Factors: Family history increases risk; mutations in ion channels (e.g., CACNA1A) can play a role.
  • Environmental Triggers: Stress, sleep disturbances, hormonal changes (especially in women), certain foods, and sensory stimuli.
  • Neurovascular Hypothesis: Migraines are believed to be caused by abnormal brain activity that affects blood vessels in the brain (dilation and constriction).
  • Cortical Spreading Depression (CSD): A wave of depolarization in the brain that may contribute to the aura phase of migraines.

Pathology

  • Cerebrovascular Changes: Involves vasodilation and neurogenic inflammation, leading to pain.
  • Neurotransmitters Involved: Serotonin (5-HT), dopamine, and CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) play roles in the pathophysiology.
  • Brainstem Activation: Migraine attacks may begin from brainstem regions (e.g., trigeminovascular system) that control sensory processing.

Classification

  • Episodic Migraine (EM): Less than 15 headache days per month.
  • Chronic Migraine (CM): More than 15 headache days per month with at least 8 days of migraine-like symptoms.
  • Migraine with Aura: Characterized by visual disturbances or other neurological symptoms before the headache.
  • Migraine without Aura: No preceding aura symptoms.

Symptoms

  • Primary Symptoms: Unilateral throbbing headache, nausea, vomiting, photophobia, and phonophobia.
  • Aura: Visual disturbances, sensory changes, or speech difficulties may precede the headache.
  • Postdrome: After the headache subsides, patients often feel fatigued, confused, or have difficulty concentrating.

Treatment: Acute and Preventive

Acute Treatment (Abortive Therapy)

  • Triptans (e.g., Sumatriptan): First-line for moderate to severe migraines; serotonin receptor agonists that reduce inflammation and vasodilation.
  • NSAIDs (e.g., Ibuprofen, Naproxen): Effective for mild to moderate migraines; reduces pain and inflammation.
  • Ergotamines (e.g., Dihydroergotamine): Less commonly used; effective but with more side effects.
  • Antiemetics (e.g., Metoclopramide): For nausea and vomiting associated with migraines.

Preventive Treatment

  • Beta-Blockers (e.g., Propranolol): First-line for prevention, especially if comorbid anxiety is present.
  • Antidepressants (e.g., Amitriptyline, Venlafaxine): Effective for depression and migraine prevention; venlafaxine has evidence for chronic migraine prevention.
  • Antiepileptics (e.g., Topiramate, Divalproex): Preventative options with efficacy in reducing migraine frequency.
  • CGRP Inhibitors (e.g., Erenumab): Newer class of drugs targeting CGRP pathways, effective in preventing migraines.
  • Botulinum Toxin: Effective in chronic migraine, especially when other treatments fail.

Non-Pharmacological Treatment

  • Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Reduces stress and anxiety, helps in chronic migraine management.
  • Biofeedback: Helps in managing stress and improving relaxation techniques.
  • Acupuncture: Some evidence suggests acupuncture can reduce migraine frequency.
  • Dietary Modifications: Avoidance of known triggers such as caffeine, chocolate, and alcohol.

Comorbidities

  • Psychiatric Comorbidities: Migraine is often comorbid with depression, anxiety, and PTSD. Addressing these conditions is crucial for effective migraine management.
  • Chronic Migraine and Medication Overuse: Chronic use of abortive medications can lead to medication overuse headaches.

Diagnostic Tools

  • Headache Diary: Tracking headache frequency, intensity, triggers, and medications used.
  • Imaging: MRI or CT is used to rule out secondary causes (e.g., tumors, structural abnormalities).
  • Screening for Comorbidities: Depression and anxiety screening is important in migraine patients.

Management of Chronic Migraine

  • Abortive Drugs: Use sparingly to avoid medication overuse headaches.
  • Preventive Therapy: A combination of pharmacological and non-pharmacological methods is essential.
  • Patient Education: Managing triggers, sleep hygiene, and regular exercise are key.

Special Considerations

  • Hormonal Migraine: Migraine that occurs around menstruation; estrogen therapy may be used in some cases.
  • Pregnancy: Non-pharmacological treatments should be prioritized, with medications like acetaminophen considered safe during pregnancy.
  • Pediatric Migraines: Triptans, NSAIDs, and behavioral treatments may be used in children, with caution.

Tags :

  • Topic : Migraine, Treatment
  • Difficulty Level: Must know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter, Page Number: 1248

questions.text: Which psychological feature is not seen in Conversion disorder/ Functional neurological symptom disorder?
questions.solution:
Option A: Primary gain

Patients achieve primary gain by keeping internal conflicts outside their awareness. Symptoms have symbolic value; they represent an unconscious psychological conflict.

Option B: Secondary gain

Patients accrue tangible advantages and benefits as a result of being sick; for example, being excused from obligations and difficult life situations, receiving support and assistance that might not otherwise be forthcoming, and controlling others’ behavior.

Option C: Projection

Projection is a defense mechanism where individuals attribute their own unacceptable thoughts, feelings, or motives to others, avoiding internal conflict.

It's often seen in disorders like paranoia or borderline personality disorder, where individuals may accuse others of harboring negative feelings or intentions that they themselves possess.

Option D: La belle indifference

La belle indifférence refers to a patient's unusual calmness or lack of concern regarding significant symptoms or impairments. While commonly associated with conversion disorder, it can also be observed in seriously ill medical patients exhibiting a stoic demeanor. Its presence is not definitive for any specific diagnosis.

Tags :

  • Topic : Conversion disorder, la belle indifference
  • Difficulty Level: Good to know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 12, Page Number:1457

choices.text: Continue the current DRA and monitor
Initiate intravenous dantrolene and stop the DRA
Start oral bromocriptine and increase DRA dosage
Administer antipsychotic medication of a different class

questions.text: A 25-year-old male on a high-potency dopamine receptor antagonist (DRA) presents with extreme hyperthermia, severe muscular rigidity, confusion, and increased pulse rate. Laboratory tests reveal elevated creatinine phosphokinase and WBC count. What is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)

  • It is a potentially fatal side effect of dopamine receptor antagonist (DRA) treatment, occurring at any time during therapy.
  • Symptoms include extreme hyperthermia, severe muscular rigidity, akinesia, confusion, agitation, and increased pulse and blood pressure.
  • Laboratory findings often reveal elevated white blood cell counts, creatinine phosphokinase, and myoglobin levels. Symptoms typically evolve over 24 to 72 hours.
  • Immediate management involves discontinuing the DRA, providing supportive care, and cooling measures. Medications like dantrolene or bromocriptine may be used to alleviate symptoms.
  • Men and younger individuals are more frequently affected, with a mortality rate of 20-30%.

Tags :

  • Topic : Antipsychotics, NMS
  • Difficulty Level: Must know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 21, Page Number: 1957

questions.text: What is the frequency of alpha wave of EEG?
questions.solution:
Electroencephalogram

  • The EEG assesses regional cerebral cortical electrical activity and has a long history in clinical neuroscience.
  • It can be modified to study specific brain states, displayed as paper tracings or digitized for color-coded topographic maps.
  • EEGs are used to monitor epilepsy, evaluate delirium, and localize seizure foci. In psychiatry, EEGs help rule out nonpsychiatric diseases but are less effective than imaging tests for conditions like strokes or tumors.
  • A normal EEG does not exclude seizure disorders.
  • Waves of EEG
    1. Alpha wave: 8-13 Hz
    2. Beta wave: 13-30 Hz
    3. Theta wave: 4-8 Hz
    4. Delta wave: 0.5-4 Hz

(Pneumonic: DTAB)


  • Lobes and corresponding EEG wave:
    1. Delta: infant, sleeping adults
    2. Theta: children, sleeping adults
    3. Alpha: occipital lobe
    4. Beta: Frontal and Parietal lobe
  • Sleep cycle and corresponding EEG wave:
    1. Stage I: NREM: vertex waves(theta)
    2. Stage II: NREM: sleep spindles, k- complexes
    3. Stage III: Deep sleep NREM: Delta waves
    4. REM sleep: fast mixed frequency waves (sawtooth waves)
    5. Active mental concentration: beta
    6. Focused attention: Gamma: highest frequency >30 hz

Tags :

  • Topic : Sleep cycle, EEG
  • Difficulty Level: Must know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 1, Page Number:216

questions.text:
A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of fluctuating weight and episodes of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting. He describes feeling a lack of control during these binge episodes and experiences intense shame afterward. He exercises excessively to "make up" for the calories consumed. His weight is within the normal range, but he expresses dissatisfaction with his body image, often feeling he is not thin enough.

What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bulimia nervosa

  • This diagnosis is consistent with the patient’s behavior of binge eating followed by compensatory actions (self-induced vomiting).
  • The feelings of lack of control during binge episodes and shame afterward are hallmark features of Bulimia Nervosa. This is the most likely diagnosis.

Option A: Anorexia nervosa

  • Anorexia Nervosa is characterized by significantly low body weight, an intense fear of gaining weight, and a distorted body image.
  • Although this patient experiences body dissatisfaction, his weight is within the normal range, and he does not restrict intake to a dangerously low level, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Option C: Binge eating disorder

  • Binge-Eating Disorder involves episodes of consuming large amounts of food without compensatory behaviors.
  • Although the patient binge eats, the presence of vomiting indicates that Bulimia Nervosa is the more accurate diagnosis.

Option D: Pica

  • Pica is an eating disorder characterized by the persistent consumption of non-nutritive, non-food substances, such as dirt, clay, paper, or chalk.
  • It often occurs in individuals with developmental disabilities or during pregnancy and can lead to serious health complications if untreated.

Tags :

  • Topic : Eating disorder, Bulimia nervosa, Anorexia nervosa, binge-eating disorder
  • Difficulty Level: Must know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 13, Page Number: 1499

choices.text: Immediate discharge with a safety plan

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after her teacher noticed she had been increasingly withdrawn and expressed feelings of worthlessness. Upon assessment, she admits to thinking about suicide but insists she wouldn't actually do it.

What is the most important consideration for this patient's management?
questions.solution:
Option B: Comprehensive psychiatric evaluation

A thorough evaluation is critical to understand the extent of the suicidal thoughts and the underlying issues. This assessment will guide the management plan, ensuring the patient's safety and appropriate treatment.

Option A: Immediate discharge with a safety plan

While a safety plan is essential, discharging the patient without a thorough psychiatric evaluation is risky. The potential for suicidal ideation requires deeper assessment to determine the appropriate level of care.

Option C: Involvement of school counselors

Engaging school counselors can be beneficial for ongoing support but is not the immediate priority. The patient's current safety and mental health need to be addressed first through a comprehensive evaluation.

Option D: Increased parental supervision

While increased supervision can help, it is not a substitute for professional assessment. The immediate focus should be on evaluating the patient's mental health and risk factors.

Tags :

  • Topic : Psychiatry emergency, Suicide
  • Difficulty Level: Must know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 25, Page Number:2587

choices.text: Functional disorders are diagnosed using brain imaging and lab tests
Functional disorders are diagnosed through clinical evaluation, interviews, and symptom history
Blood tests are the primary diagnostic tool for functional disorders
Functional disorders are diagnosed only by ruling out organic disorders

questions.text: Which of the following is true about diagnosing functional mental disorders?
questions.solution:
Functional mental disorders are primarily diagnosed through clinical interviews and symptom history, as there are no specific physical tests to identify these conditions. Organic disorders, however, rely on medical imaging and lab tests.

Organic Mental Disorders:

  • Cause: Result from identifiable physical changes or damage to the brain (e.g., trauma, infections, strokes, neurodegenerative diseases, substance abuse).
  • Symptoms: Cognitive decline, memory loss, behavioral changes, altered mental states (e.g., confusion, delirium).
  • Diagnosis: Involves imaging (CT/MRI), neuropsychological testing, blood tests, and sometimes genetic testing.
  • Treatment: Focuses on addressing the physical cause (e.g., surgery, medication) with cognitive rehabilitation as adjunctive care.
  • Examples: Dementia, delirium, traumatic brain injury (TBI).

Functional Mental Disorders:

  • Cause: Arise from psychological, emotional, or social factors without detectable brain damage.
  • Symptoms: Mood swings, delusions, hallucinations, excessive worry, and altered reality perceptions.
  • Diagnosis: Primarily based on clinical interviews and symptom history, without specific physical tests.
  • Treatment: Includes psychotherapy (e.g., CBT), medications (e.g., antidepressants, antipsychotics), and lifestyle changes.
  • Examples: Depression, schizophrenia, anxiety disorders.

Assessment and Differentiation:

  • Diagnosis: Organic disorders are diagnosed through imaging and medical tests; functional disorders through clinical evaluation.
  • Symptom Presentation: Organic disorders often show physical signs linked to specific brain areas; functional disorders show more varied and abstract symptoms.
  • Treatment Approaches: Organic disorders may require medical or surgical treatment; functional disorders are typically treated with psychological therapies and medications.
  • Prognosis: Organic disorder prognosis depends on the physical condition (e.g., neurodegenerative disease progression), while functional disorders can improve with treatment but may relapse.

Key Differences:

  • Cause: Organic disorders involve observable brain damage; functional disorders stem from psychological or emotional causes.
  • Diagnosis: Organic disorders are identified via imaging and lab tests, while functional disorders are diagnosed via clinical evaluation.
  • Treatment: Organic disorders require medical or surgical interventions; functional disorders are treated with therapy and medications.

Tags :

  • Topic: Functional vs organic mental disorders
  • Difficulty Level: May know

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Chapter 35, Page Number: 3556
